Located on a fueling pier at least 20 feet and not further than 100 feet from a dispenser; and
Identified by a sign stating “EMERGENCY PUMP SHUTOFF” in 2-inch minimum red capital letters;
The fuel dispensing system, including each dispenser, dispenser hose and nozzle, at the marina:
Is UL listed or approved for the fuel being dispensed;
Is compatible with the product piping;
Has a containment sump that does not leak; and
Has a UL listed shear valve placed and properly anchored at the dispenser in accordance with manufacturer requirements;
Each fuel delivery nozzle on a dispenser used for fueling vessels is an automatic-closing type without a latch-open device;

One or more signs are posted in the dispensing area that provide instructions to the public on vessel fueling procedures in accordance with Section 11.10.8 of NFPA 30A “Code for Motor Fuel Dispensing Facilities and Repair Garages”;
If the hose length of a dispenser hose is greater than 18 feet, the dispenser hose is secured by a hose reel;
Underground piping:
Between an AST and the bulkhead complies with COMAR 26.10.03.02 and 26.10.05.01 and .02; and
May be used between the bulkhead and the dispenser only if the underground piping has UL listed flexible double-walled construction:
Rated for aboveground, overwater, or underwater use by the piping manufacturer; or
Not rated for aboveground, overwater, or underwater use by the piping manufacturer, but the piping is sleeved in rigid, corrosion-resistant pipe meeting a minimum 2-hour fire rating; and
The transition piping between the bulkhead and a floating pier:
Includes:
A reducing seal at the bulkhead;
Non-corrosive pipe supports;
An in-line breakaway that seals both ends of the piping;
Single plane swivel joints with flanged fittings; and
Fire-rated flex connectors; and
Connects to the floating pier piping in a leak-proof containment sump with:
A manual ball valve in the product line;
A solenoid valve that is closed when the emergency pump shutoff is activated or when no fueling is occurring; and
A sump sensor that triggers a positive system shutdown.
An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a marina shall:
Provide an attendant during vessel fueling activities and the attendant shall:
Be familiar with the dispensing systems and emergency shutoff controls;
Prevent the dispensing of oil into improper portable containers;
Ensure vessels are properly moored and all fueling connections are made;
Be within 15 feet of the dispensing controls during a fueling operation; and
Maintain a direct, clear, and unobstructed view of both the vessel fuel filler neck and the emergency pump shutoff; and
Provide a spill response box near to a fuel dispensing area that:
Stores a sufficient quantity of sorbent materials that can float on water to contain a minimum of 25 gallons of oil; and
The person in charge of the marina inspects monthly to ensure supplies of sorbent materials are maintained.

An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall obtain an Individual Oil Operations Permit to conduct an oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste solidification/stabilization operation.
Permit Application and Issuance Procedures.

An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall apply for an Individual Oil Operations Permit in accordance with Regulations .09A and .11 of this chapter, and include the following information in the permit application:
A to-scale site diagram that identifies the:
Location of each solidification/stabilization process area;
Direction of stormwater flow at the facility;
Storm drains on-site and immediately off-site; and
Location of buildings and property lines, identifying the owners of any adjacent properties; and
A detailed description of:
The solidification/stabilization process;

The testing or verification to be completed prior to accepting oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste intended for solidification/stabilization to ensure the oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste does not contain a hazardous substance or originate from a gasoline storage tank system; and

How the facility will maintain records of tracking and testing for each batch of raw material to be solidified/stabilized and for loads of processed material transferred to a permitted disposal facility.
Upon review of an application completed in accordance with this regulation, the Department shall:

Notify the applicant in writing that the application is not complete and additional information is required to determine whether the proposed oil solidification/stabilization operation is consistent with all applicable requirements of this chapter, COMAR 26.10, and other State laws and regulations;
Issue an Individual Oil Operations Permit to the applicant in accordance with Regulation .11G and H of this chapter; or
Deny the application for an Individual Oil Operations Permit in accordance with Regulation .12 of this chapter.

An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall apply to renew an Individual Oil Operations Permit in accordance with §B(1) of this regulation and Regulation .11E of this chapter.
In accordance with Regulation .12B of this chapter, the Department may:
Deny an application for an Individual Oil Operations Permit for a proposed oil solidification/stabilization operation; or
Suspend or revoke an Individual Oil Operations Permit under which an oil solidification/stabilization operation is permitted.

The Department may modify, or an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility may request to modify, the oil solidification/stabilization conditions of an Individual Oil Operations Permit in accordance with Regulation .12B of this chapter.
Operation and Recordkeeping Conditions. An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility conducting an oil solidification/stabilization operation:
May not accept oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste that contains:
A hazardous substance; or
Sludge, refuse, or other mixed waste from a gasoline storage tank system;
May not cause or allow the unpermitted discharge of stormwater entering the solidification/stabilization process area into waters of the State;
Shall ensure stormwater entering the solidification/stabilization process area is either:
Included in the solidification/stabilization process;
Managed under a State discharge permit or National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit; or
Disposed of at a facility permitted for the treatment of oily water;
Shall complete the following tasks at the end of each working day:
Clean the area surrounding the solidification/stabilization area of all oily substances; and
Cover and secure the solidification/stabilization process area so that the contents are not exposed to stormwater;
Shall dispose of the end product from the solidification/stabilization process at a State or USEPA permitted disposal facility;
Shall maintain the following records for at least 5 years at the oil storage facility or oil handling facility:
Certification by a generator of oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste that the material is in compliance with §C(1) of this regulation;

Analytical data demonstrating the oil sludge, oil refuse, or oil mixed with other waste accepted at the oil storage facility or oil handling facility is in compliance with §C(1) of this regulation; and
A copy of each approval from the receiving facility where the oil solidification/stabilization end product was accepted and disposed, including analytical data; and
In addition to the requirements under §C(1)—(6) of this regulation, shall comply with the Individual Oil Operations Permit conditions under Regulation .09A of this chapter.

section.heading: Requirements for Oil Delivery by Truck Tanks and Transports.

para.text: A permittee and a person in charge of the transportation, transfer, or delivery of oil shall use:
A truck tank or transport equipped with transfer hoses and fittings of a grade suitable for the type of oil transferred and for the type of delivery;
A truck tank or transport equipped with transfer hoses designed to withstand pressure of the shut-off head of the cargo pump or pump relief valve setting; and
Vehicles that are in compliance with:
The Maryland Department of Transportation requirements for transportation of hazardous materials under COMAR 11.16.01 and motor carrier safety under COMAR 11.21.01; and
NFPA 385 “Standard for Tank Vehicles for Flammable and Combustible Liquids”.
A permittee and a person in charge of the transportation, transfer, or delivery of oil by truck tank or transport shall:
Provide a driver safety training program annually that instructs drivers employed by the permittee or the person in charge on:
Truck tank, transport, and oil delivery operations;
The oil pollution control and storage tank system provisions in COMAR 26.10.01—26.10.04, 26.10.17, and 26.10.18;
The requirement for the reporting, containment, and removal of an oil spill, release, or discharge; and
The conditions of the permittee’s Individual Oil Operations Permit;
Ensure a driver employed by the permittee or the person in charge is knowledgeable of and follows the requirements under Regulation .17 of this chapter;
Maintain records demonstrating compliance with the training requirement under §B(1) of this regulation;
Within 30 days of hire, provide a truck tank or transport driver with safety training in accordance with §B(1) of this regulation;
Provide each truck tank or transport with:
Materials to be used for the prompt containment and removal of an oil spill, release, or discharge; and
One portable fire extinguisher that has a minimum rating of 4-A:40-B:C, or at least two portable fire extinguishers with a rating of 2-A:20-B:C;

Ensure the Department’s emergency spill reporting telephone number listed in the Individual Oil Operations Permit is conspicuously posted in each truck tank and transport authorized under the permit for the transportation, transfer, or delivery of oil;
Meet insurance requirements for the transportation, transfer, and delivery of oil;
On an annual basis or at least every 25,000 miles, perform preventative maintenance on a truck tank or transport in accordance with 49 CFR Part 396 and COMAR 11.14;
Inspect and test each truck tank and transport used for the transportation of flammable petroleum liquids in accordance with 49 CFR §180.407;
Obtain and properly display a:
U.S. Department of Transportation number for each interstate truck tank or transport the permittee or the person in charge uses in the transportation, transfer, or delivery of oil; and
Maryland State Highway Administration identification number for each intrastate truck tank or transport the permittee or the person in charge uses in the transportation, transfer, or delivery of oil;
Register each placarded truck tank or transport in accordance with 49 CFR Part 107; and
Meet zoning requirements for commercial vehicles when parking a truck tank or transport in the State.
A permittee and a person in charge may not deliver oil by truck tank or transport to:
A UST system that is not registered with the Department in accordance with COMAR 26.10.03.09;
An AST system that is not registered with the Department in accordance with Regulation .10 of this chapter;
An oil storage tank in which the Department has:
In accordance with COMAR 26.10.02.03C, issued a notice of a delivery ban to the owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the oil storage tank system; and
Affixed a monitoring device, such as a tag, notice, or locking mechanism, to the fill; or
A storage tank system or a residential heating oil tank that is:
Visibly spilling or releasing oil;
In poor or damaged condition; or
In an unstable condition.
A person may not fuel or refuel a vessel from a truck tank or transport at a public marina.
Class II liquid from a truck tank or transport may be dispensed to a vessel located at a commercial, industrial, government, or manufacturing facility if the following requirements are met:
The vessel is used in connection with the facility’s business;
The owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the facility controls access to the fueling or refueling area, with the fueling or refueling area not accessible to the general public;
The dispensing hose does not exceed 50 feet in length;
The dispensing nozzle is a UL listed, automatic-closing type without a latch-open device;
A nighttime delivery only occurs in an area that is adequately lighted;
The driver or the person in charge at the facility ensures the flasher lights of the truck tank or transport are in operation during all fueling and refueling activities;
The driver ensures there is adequate fuel expansion space left in each fuel tank of the vessel being filled to prevent a spill, release, or discharge because of temperature increase; and
The owner, the operator, and the person in charge of a facility where the oil is delivered by truck tank or transport to a vessel:
Maintains sufficient spill containment materials for a spill, release, or discharge of, at a minimum, 100 gallons of oil on land or in waters of the State; and
Locates the spill containment materials in an easily identifiable area near to where fueling operations occur.

section.heading: Requirements for Drivers of Truck Tanks and Transports.

para.text: A driver operating a truck tank or a transport shall:
Comply with NFPA 385 “Standard for Tank Vehicles for Flammable and Combustible Liquids”;
Be 21 years old or older as required under Transportation Article, §25-111, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Complete annual safety training provided in accordance with Regulation .16B of this chapter.
A driver shall load and unload a truck tank or transport only in an approved location.
A driver may not deliver to a storage tank, including a residential heating oil tank, when any of the following conditions are observed:
The Department has:
In accordance with COMAR 26.10.02.03C, issued a notice of a delivery ban to the owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the oil storage tank system; and
Affixed a monitoring device, such as a tag, notice, or locking mechanism, to the fill;
The storage tank system is visibly spilling or releasing oil; or
An AST system is in poor, unstable, or damaged condition.
Before a transfer of oil begins, the driver shall:
Verify that:
Proper hoses and fittings will be used in the delivery of oil;
The transfer hoses are not damaged; and
All transfer hose connections are tight; and
Confirm, for direct or remote filling operations, the storage tank has sufficient ullage available to hold the amount of oil being delivered by implementing one or more of the following methods:
Gauge the storage tank and record ullage and amount of oil delivered;
Use a functioning vent whistle or other overfill device;
Verify with the facility’s person in charge:
The size of the storage tank being delivered to and the quantity of oil to be delivered;
That the storage tank has an approved and functional overfill alarm; or
For remote filling, that a representative from the facility will actively participate in the filling operation; or
Use another method approved by the Department.
During a transfer of oil, the driver shall:
Be alert and outside the vehicle;
Remain within 10 feet and in full and immediate control of the nozzle, shut-off valves, pumps, and emergency operating mechanism for the discharge control valve; and
Have the fill pipe opening in full view at all times.

If a driver leaves the equipment unattended for any reason, the driver shall turn off or return to the closed position all nozzles, shut-off valves, pumps, and discharge control valves of the truck tank or transport and the receiving facility.
A driver may not drain oil or empty hoses into a spill catchment basin.
A driver shall immediately report to the delivery company any unusual conditions observed during a transfer operation including, but not limited to:
A spill, release, or discharge;
A discrepancy between the quantity of oil delivered and the quantity of oil received;
Equipment defects on the delivery vehicle or at a transfer location; and
Unsafe delivery conditions.
A driver, permittee, and person in charge of a delivery company shall report a spill, release, or discharge made during an oil delivery in accordance with Regulation .05 of this chapter.

section.heading: Requirements for Oil Transfers at Facilities.

para.text: The requirements of this regulation are applicable to oil storage facilities and oil handling facilities with tank car, truck tank, or transport loading/unloading racks or transfer areas.
Spill Control.

For a loading/unloading rack or transfer area at an oil storage facility or oil handling facility where a spill, release, or discharge can occur during transfer operations, an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of the facility shall:
Pave the loading/unloading rack or transfer area with a material that has a permeability of 10-7 centimeters/second or less and is resistant to oil;
Maintain the pavement installed in accordance with §B(1)(a) of this regulation to prevent cracking and holes;
Design the loading/unloading rack or transfer area to prevent the entrance of stormwater or wastewater runoff into the loading/unloading rack or transfer area;
Cover the loading/unloading rack or transfer area with a roof;
Include a containment system that prevents oil or stormwater containing oil from discharging to waters of the State by:
Being designed to hold a spill, release, or discharge from the largest single compartment of any tank car, truck tank, or transport loading or unloading oil at the facility; and
Using permanent curbing, trenching, or other spill control methods approved by the Department; and
Install one or more of the following to prevent a spill, release, or discharge of oil:
An oil/water separator;
A diked or bermed catchment area that has a permeability of 10-7 centimeters/second or less; or
An emergency underground holding tank that remains empty unless a spill, release, or discharge occurs.

An owner of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility with a loading/unloading rack or transfer area may be required to obtain a State discharge permit or a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit issued by the Department under Environment Article, §9-323, Annotated Code of Maryland and COMAR 26.08.01—26.08.04 for discharges of stormwater to waters of the State.
If oil is spilled, released, or discharged during an oil transfer, an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall:
Report the spill, release, or discharge immediately to the Department in accordance with Regulation .05 of this chapter;
Immediately begin the removal of oil; and
Handle the oil and all removal debris in accordance with all State, federal, and local requirements.

An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall make available at a loading/unloading rack or transfer area removal materials, such as sorbents:
That are appropriate for:
The grades of oil being transferred; and
The most probable size of an anticipated spill, release, or discharge; and
For use in the containment and removal of spilled, released, or discharged oil.
Transfer Operations. An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall:

Install a clearly identifiable switch or shutoff at the loading/unloading rack and at a remote location from the loading/unloading rack area to shut off power to all transfer devices in the event of an emergency;

Provide an interlocking warning light or physical barrier system, warning signs, wheel chocks, or vehicle brake interlock system to prevent a tank car, truck tank, or transport from leaving a loading/unloading area or transfer area before flexible or fixed oil transfer lines are disconnected;

Prior to filling and departure at the oil storage facility or oil handling facility, inspect the lowermost drain and all outlets on the tank car, truck tank, or transport for spills, releases, or discharges; and

If a spill, release, or discharge is found during an inspection, repair or replace the lowermost drain and all outlets on the tank car, truck tank, or transport prior to entering a public transportation system.

section.heading: Right to Information and Facility Access.
section.text: As a condition for the issuance of an Individual Oil Operations Permit or authorization to operate under a General Oil Operations Permit, the permittee and the person in charge of an oil storage facility or oil handling facility shall, upon the request of the Department:

para.text: Provide to the Department information and copies of records required under:
The provisions of COMAR 26.10;
Environment Article, §§4-401—4-420, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
A condition of the permit;
Allow the Department to conduct monitoring;
Complete any survey forms or other documents provided by the Department in a timely manner;

Make the facility available for inspection by the Secretary or the Secretary’s authorized representative, including the inspection of storage tank systems, equipment, vehicles, or vessels used in the operation of the oil storage facility or oil handling facility; and
During an inspection of the facility:
Make all records pertaining to the facility and the operation of the facility available for inspection;
Allow the Department to:
Make copies of data, records, and information pertaining to the facility and the operation of the facility;
Collect air, surface or groundwater, soil, and vegetation samples or samples of other materials on-site as determined necessary by the Department; and
Obtain photographic or videographic documentation or evidence.

section.heading: Requirements for Motor Fuel Dispensing Facilities.

para.text: The requirements of this regulation apply to an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility.
An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility shall install and operate a storage tank system in accordance with the requirements of COMAR 26.10 as follows:
Install and operate a UST system in accordance with:
The requirements of this chapter, COMAR 26.10.02—26.10.12, and 26.10.16; and
The applicable documents incorporated by reference under Regulation .03 of this chapter;
Install and operate an AST system in accordance with:
The requirements of this chapter and COMAR 26.10.17 and 26.10.18; and
The applicable documents incorporated by reference under Regulation .03 of this chapter; and
If the motor fuel dispensing facility is located at a marina, comply with the requirements of Regulation .14 of this chapter.
An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility may not allow the dispensing of motor fuel at the facility unless:
The location is attended;
The owner, the operator, and the person in charge has received prior written approval from the Department to operate the location as an unattended motor fuel dispensing facility; or
The location is a commercial, industrial, governmental, or manufacturing property where motor fuels are dispensed into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles or vessels that are:
Owned or controlled by the owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the facility; and
Used in connection with the business or operation of that property by persons within the employ of such business or operation.

The Department may not provide written approval to an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a marina with a motor fuel dispensing facility to operate the motor fuel dispensing facility unattended.

Pursuant to §C(2) of this regulation, the Department may provide written approval to an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility to operate the location unattended if the owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the facility:
Provide each customer with a unique means of authorization, such as a key card, membership card, or other method that identifies the specific customer;
Ensure the dispensers at the facility require a customer to input the unique authorization required under §E(1) of this regulation in order for motor fuel to be dispensed;
Install an emergency shut-off device or electrical disconnect that is readily accessible to customers for each group of dispensers on an individual dispenser island;

Confirm with the State Fire Marshall or local fire department whether the owner, the operator, and the person in charge of the motor fuel dispensing facility needs to employ additional fire protections such as:
Installing fixed suppression systems, automatic fire detection systems, or manual fire alarm stations;
Transmitting alarms to an off-site supervising fire alarm station located at the oil storage facility or another off-site location; or
Limiting the quantity of motor fuel dispensed per transaction;

Provide the Department with documentation that confirms the installation of any additional fire protection methods at the facility under the direction of the State Fire Marshall or local fire department, as required under §E(4) of this regulation;
Conspicuously post operating instructions, warning signs, and emergency instructions in the dispensing area in accordance with NFPA 30A “Code for Motor Fuel Dispensing Facilities and Repair Garages”;

Provide on-site in a readily accessible location a telephone or other approved clearly identifiable means to notify the fire department in accordance with NFPA 30A “Code for Motor Fuel Dispensing Facilities and Repair Garages”;

On a sign visible from the dispensing area that is not less than 8 x 10 inches in size with lettering not less than 1-inch high, conspicuously post emergency telephone numbers for contacting the following persons in the event of a suspected or confirmed spill, release or discharge, unusual operating conditions, emergency, or equipment failure:
Emergency response authorities;
A person in charge at the facility; and
The Department;
Provide at least one readily available spill containment kit clearly labeled and stored on-site to contain spills, releases, or discharges of less than 20 gallons; and

If the facility is a regulated substance storage facility, comply with the operator training requirements for designated Class A operators, Class B operators, and Class C operators of unattended facilities in accordance with COMAR 26.10.16.

If the Department determines that an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of an approved unattended motor fuel dispensing facility is not maintaining the operations of the facility in accordance with §E of this regulation, the Department may:
For a UST system, issue a notice of a delivery ban in accordance with COMAR 26.10.02.03C; and
For an AST system, suspend or revoke an Individual or General Oil Operations Permit in accordance with Regulation .12 of this chapter.

An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility with a sanitary sewer or storm drain connection receiving oil-bearing waste or wastewater from operations at the motor fuel dispensing facility shall:
Comply with one of the following requirements:
If oil-bearing waste or wastewater enters a publicly-owned wastewater treatment system, obtain and operate under a Pretreatment Permit issued by:
The local municipal wastewater treatment utility with delegated authority by the Department to administer a Pretreatment Program in accordance with COMAR 26.08.08; or
The Department if the local municipal wastewater treatment utility does not have delegated authority to administer a Pretreatment Program; or
If oil-bearing waste or wastewater enter into a storm drain system, install an oil/water separating system that is properly:
Designed to accommodate a worst case incident of a spill, release, or discharge;
Operated by a person in charge of the motor fuel dispensing facility;
Maintained to manufacturer specifications;
Inspected monthly; and
Pumped out when oil has accumulated to greater than 1 inch in the retention chamber; and

Obtain all the required permits for the sanitary sewer or storm drain connection receiving oil-bearing waste or wastewater from operations at the motor fuel dispensing facility in accordance with federal, State and local laws and regulations.
A person in charge of a motor fuel dispensing facility shall dispose of used oil generated at the motor fuel dispensing facility:
In accordance with COMAR 26.10.15;
In a manner that prevents a spill, release, or discharge; and
Using disposal methods required under applicable federal, State and local laws and regulations.
An owner, an operator, and a person in charge of a motor fuel dispenser facility may not install or use a dispenser hose that is greater than 18 feet in length.
Response Plan.

An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility required to have an approved response plan under 33 CFR Part 154, Subpart F may not operate the marine oil facility unless the owner, the operator, and the marine oil facility are in full compliance with federal requirements for a response plan.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall include in a response plan, at a minimum:
Training elements;
Oil spill, release, or discharge contingency elements;
Removal equipment elements; and
All of the elements required to be included in a response plan under 33 CFR Part 154, Subpart F.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall provide to the Department a current response plan as part of an application for:
A new Individual Oil Operations Permit; and
A renewal of an Individual Oil Operations Permit.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall implement all of the elements of an approved response plan in accordance with the schedule of compliance in 33 CFR Part 154, Subpart F.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall:
Maintain an approved response plan at the marine oil facility; and
Make the approved response plan available for review upon request by the Department.
Spill, Release, and Discharge Prevention at Marine Oil Facilities.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall institute safe fill and shutdown procedures to prevent oil spills, releases, or discharges:
During an oil transfer operation; and
In the event of an overfill of a storage tank.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall include in the procedures required under §B(1) of this regulation, at a minimum, the following elements:

Prior to commencing an oil transfer operation, an owner, an operator, and a person in charge of the marine oil facility confirms that the volume available in the receiving storage tank is greater than the volume of oil to be transferred;
The continuous monitoring of an oil transfer operation by manual or automatic means until the transfer of oil is complete;
A storage tank fill valve not in use during an oil transfer operation is closed and secured; and
The transfer of oil only occurs into a storage tank designated to receive the oil.
Shutdown System or Alarm.
Storage tanks receiving asphalt (CAS8052424) from a tank vessel are exempt from the requirements of §B(3) of this regulation.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall:

Install an automatic shutdown system on each storage tank to be used during the transfer of oil from a tank vessel that will, in the event of an overfill, direct the flow of oil to another storage tank capable of receiving the oil or shut down the pumping system; or
Equip each AST used in the transfer of oil from a tank vessel with a high level alarm.
If an AST is equipped with a high level alarm in accordance with §B(3)(b)(ii) of this regulation, an owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall install a high level alarm that:
Consists of a device capable of visually and audibly alerting the owner and the operator of the marine oil facility of an impending storage tank overfill; and

If a failure, malfunction, or power loss occurs during the transfer of oil, causes a warning light and audible signal to activate at a location in which the owner and the operator of the marine oil facility monitors or controls oil transfers at the facility.
If a high level alarm sounds, an owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall initiate an immediate and orderly emergency shutdown of the oil transfer.

An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility using a high level alarm shall include an emergency shutdown procedure in the facility records and ensure that all facility personnel involved in the transfer operation are trained in the emergency shutdown procedure.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall ensure that an automatic shutdown system or high level alarm system is tested:
Monthly; or
Before a receipt of oil.
An owner and an operator of a marine oil facility shall:
Maintain records of testing at the marine oil facility; and
Make the records of testing available for review by a representative of the Department upon request.
Response Plan.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall comply with the requirements of §A(2)—(4) of this regulation.

An owner and an operator of a tank vessel required to have an approved response plan under 33 CFR Part 155, Subpart D may not operate the tank vessel in the State unless the owner and the operator of the tank vessel and the tank vessel are in full compliance with federal requirements for a response plan.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall include in a response plan, at a minimum:
Training elements;
Oil spill, release, or discharge contingency elements;
Removal equipment elements; and
All of the elements required to be included in a response plan under 33 CFR Part 155, Subpart D.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall make an approved response plan available for review by a representative of the Department upon request.
Detection and Control of Oil Spills, Releases, and Discharges.
All-weather Escort Tank Vessel.
The requirements of §B(1) and (2) of this regulation do not apply to a public vessel.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall ensure that a tank vessel transporting oil in the State is accompanied by an all-weather escort vessel.
The crew on an escort vessel shall continuously check for any evidence of an oil spill, release, or discharge from the escorted tank vessel.
A vessel supplying propulsion to the tank vessel does not fulfill the requirement for an all-weather escort vessel.
Alternative Monitoring. In lieu of meeting the escort vessel requirement under §B(1) of this regulation, an owner and an operator of a tank vessel may:
Equip the tank vessel with a cargo level monitoring system;
Ensure the tank vessel’s double hulls are designed in compliance with 33 CFR §157.10(d); or

Have a Department approved plan prepared by the owner and the operator of the tank vessel that provides for visual or another method of inspection of load lines or draft markings for the tank vessel that will determine the existence of an oil spill, release, or discharge from the tank vessel.
Cargo Level Monitoring System. An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall:
Maintain the cargo level monitoring system of the tank vessel in full working order; and
Correct a malfunction of equipment before getting the tank vessel underway.
Inspection Requirements.
The requirements of this section do not apply to a public vessel.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel transporting oil in the State shall inspect the tank vessel in accordance with 46 U.S.C. Subtitle II, Part B and 46 CFR Part 2.

The Department may require an owner and an operator of a tank vessel to perform additional inspections if the Department has reason to believe the tank vessel has been damaged or responsible for one or more spills, releases, or discharges due to structural damage.
An owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall display a certificate of inspection issued under 46 U.S.C. Subtitle II, Part B and 46 CFR Part 2 in a conspicuous place on the tank vessel.

The terms “assets”, “current assets”, “current liabilities”, “liabilities”, “net working capital”, “net worth”, “parent corporation”, and “tangible net worth” as used in §D of this regulation have the meanings stated in 40 CFR §264.141.
Exceptions.
The requirements of this regulation do not apply to a public vessel.

An owner and an operator of a tank vessel transferring greater than 25 barrels of oil in bulk as cargo in waters of the State may not be required to obtain a bond or other security for the tank vessel if:
The tank vessel is carrying oil removed from:
Waters of the State as the result of a spill, release, or discharge or at the request of the Department, the federal government, or a person responsible for the discharge; or
Another vessel because of the threat of a spill, release, or discharge into waters of the State; and
The tank vessel is not owned or operated by the person responsible for the discharge resulting in the need for removal of oil from waters of the State.

Bonding Requirement. Upon entering waters of the State to transfer greater than 25 barrels of oil in bulk as cargo, an owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall post a bond or other security as set forth in §D of this regulation:
In the amount of $500 per gross ton of tank vessel; and
In a form approved by the Department.

Other Acceptable Forms of Security. In lieu of posting a bond, an owner and an operator of a tank vessel may satisfy the requirement under §C of this regulation by posting another acceptable form of security that meets the conditions under §D(1) or (2) of this regulation:
A certification signed by a certified public accountant that the owner and the operator of the tank vessel has:
Two out of the three following ratios:
A ratio of total liabilities to net worth of less than 2.0;
A ratio of the sum of net income plus depreciation, depletion, and amortization to total liabilities of greater than 0.1; or
A ratio of current assets to current liabilities of greater than 1.5;
Net working capital and tangible net worth that are individually at least six times the bond amount required under §C(1) of this regulation;
Tangible net worth of at least $10,000,000; and
Assets located in the United States amounting to at least:
90 percent of total assets; or
Six times the bond amount required under §C(1) of this regulation; or
A certification signed by a certified public accountant that the owner and the operator of the tank vessel has:
A current rating for the most recent bond issuance of:
AAA, AA, A, or BBB as issued by the Standard and Poor’s (S&P); or
Aaa, Aa, A, or Baa as issued by Moody’s;
A parent corporation that meets the requirements of §D(1)(b)—(d) of this regulation; and
An absolute guaranty by the parent corporation of the owner and the operator of the tank vessel.

An owner and an operator of a tank vessel may satisfy §C of this regulation by offering proof to the Department of a current Certificate of Financial Responsibility issued to the owner and the operator of the tank vessel by the USCG under 33 CFR Part 138 for each tank vessel of the owner and the operator entering waters of the State.
The Department may waive the requirements of this regulation if the Department determines that the bonds or other securities required under this regulation are not generally available.
Bond Forfeiture.

If the Department determines that a spill, release, or discharge into waters of the State originated from a tank vessel, the bond or other security posted by the owner and the operator of the tank vessel is forfeited and becomes due and payable to the Department to the extent of:
The costs incurred by the Department to eliminate the residue of the oil spill, release, or discharge;
Damage caused to the natural and recreational resources of the State; and
Any uncollectible penalty levied against the owner and the operator of the tank vessel; and

If a bond or other security is forfeited to the Department as described in §G(1) of this regulation, an owner and an operator of a tank vessel shall post a new bond or other security for the tank vessel in accordance with §C of this regulation.
As authorized under Environment Article, §4-412, Annotated Code of Maryland:
The Department shall issue and cause to be served a written complaint:
To an alleged violator of a provision of Environment Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland or of any oil pollution control and storage tank management provision of COMAR 26.10; and
That specifies the following information:
The provision of law, rule, or regulation allegedly violated; and
The alleged fact or facts that constitute the violation;
Subsequent to or concurrent with the service of the complaint authorized under §A(1) of this regulation, the Department may issue to an alleged violator:
An order requiring the alleged violator take necessary corrective action within the time prescribed in the order;
A notice requiring an alleged violator file a written report with the Department regarding the alleged violation;
A notice requiring the alleged violator to appear before the Department at a time and place the Department specifies to answer the charge outlined in the complaint; or

A notice requiring the alleged violator file a written report with the Department regarding the alleged violation and appear before the Department at a time and place the Department specifies to answer the charges outlined in the complaint; and
If the Department exercises one of the options provided under §A(2)(b)—(d) of this regulation, the Department:

May not issue an order to the alleged violator that requires corrective action be taken as a result of the alleged violation before expiration of the time set for filing a written report and for holding a hearing required under §A(2)(b)—(d) of this regulation; and

May issue an order requiring corrective action be taken within the time prescribed in the order, after the expiration of the time set for filing the written report and holding the hearing required under §A(2)(b)—(d) of this regulation.
Contested Case Hearing.

Filing a Hearing Request. A person shall have an opportunity for a contested case hearing if the person files a written request with the Department not later than 10 calendar days after being served with:
An order from the Department requiring a corrective action issued under §A(2)(a) of this regulation; or
A notice from the Department requiring the person to file a written report regarding an alleged violation issued under §A(2)(b) of this regulation.

The appearance of the alleged violator before the Department in accordance with §A(2)(c) or (d) of this regulation constitutes an administrative hearing, and the party shall have the rights of any party in a contested case provided under State Government Article, §§10-205, 10-208 and 10-209, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A person issued an order provided under §A(3)(b) of this regulation may not request a hearing as a result of the order.
Notwithstanding a person’s right to a contested case hearing, an order issued to a person pursuant to this regulation is effective immediately upon service according to its terms.
The Department shall conduct a hearing in accordance with the provisions under State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Judicial Review. A person aggrieved by an order issued by the Department may obtain immediate judicial review under the provisions of State Government Article, §§10-222 and 10-223, Annotated Code of Maryland and the Maryland Rules.
